Starting last fall, we set out to determine RePublic‚Äôs first set of organizational core values. After surveying our scholars, families, and staff, we developed a set of five values. These values both define who we are as a network today and who we hope to be in the future. We are proud to share those core values with you over the next few days.

We are kicking things off with our first core value, Lead for Racial Equity. We‚Äôve defined this value as, ‚Äúwe believe that racism‚Äôs legacy in education is most entrenched in the South. We look at ourselves first, reflect, and talk about the role racism plays in our lives. We work to be constantly anti-racist in our words and actions.‚Äù We began working to better live this core value out over the summer and will continue to focus on it as the year progresses. Liberty Collegiate Academy Assistant Principal Melissa Cobb had this to share about Lead for Racial Equity #ThisIsRePublic #CoreValues

post_text: We at RePublic Schools are outraged and heartbroken by the events surrounding the recent deaths of black Americans George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and Ahmaud Arbery. As a network, it is our responsibility to hold our scholars, families, and staff members close as we are forced, once again, to grapple with the fatal ramifications of systemic racism and injustices in our society. We also have a responsibility to continue to look at ourselves, reflect, and talk about the role racism plays in our lives and work. We also have a responsibility as a community to think about ways to actively dismantle racism and injustice, which is why we launched our recent voter registration campaign. However, for our families who need resources to help your child process our world today, we recommend this list from the Center for Racial Justice. Know that we at RePublic Schools will continue to work to be anti-racist in our words and actions #ThisIsRePublic

Jackson Families! We are closely following the flooding threats affecting the greater Jackson area. At this point, there are no changes to our school schedule. Please continue to follow our social media for updates on our schedule and/or potential transportation changes!

Your family‚Äôs safety is our number one priority. You can follow WLBT 3 On Your Side or 16 WAPT News for more information about flooding in your area.

Also, if you find yourself in need of assistance, including shelter and/or supplies, you can call 1-800-REDCROSS (1-800-733-2767), visit www.redcross.org/get-help, or download the free Red Cross Emergency App.

You can also check with your local officials for information on where to find a shelter. The Emergency App provides emergency alerts and information about what to do in case of emergencies such as tornadoes and flooding. Users can find it in smartphone app stores by searching for the American Red Cross or going to redcross.org/apps.
